content.description: A continuous, thin crack that meanders through a featured face characterizes this cool climb. After a bit of a chossy start, the line cuts hard right to a jug that marks the beginning of a more plumb-line section of the crack. Finish up in a cool, left-facing corner that's a bit harder than it looks from the ground. The anchor lacks bolts and consists of a ratty static line tied to a tree 6' back from the top of the cliff. I'd advise bringing some long webbing (or a bolt kit!).
content.protection: Go heavy on the thin gear. Nuts are useful, as are doubles of small cams.
content.location: Look for the thin splitter on the right side of the cliff, just to the right of Fine Line (which is two routes to the right of Pub Rats).

content.description:
This route shares the first 2 bolts with

Fact Check

then moves left to another bolt gaining the left-facing corner crack. Enjoy fun well-protected moves up the corner, then move left across face to anchor on top of Jay's Upper Route.
content.protection: 3 bolts, several small to finger-size cams, 1 hand-size cam, to lowering anchor on J.U.R.
content.location: On the Upper Tier, this is the next route 50 feet to the right of Jay's Upper Route. Start on stacked blocks to ledge and first bolt.

content.description: This is a nice consistent route with a crux about halfway depending on which way you go. It's harder staying left after the 3rd bolt, maybe 11-. Otherwise head up and right to flakes on right edge of wall.
content.location: This is the first route you come to as you approach the main sector of the Upper Tier, It's in the trees 40 feet left of Jay's Upper Route.

content.description:
This is a good new (maybe last?) addition to the Upper Tier. It has varied, interesting, well-protected climbing on mostly excellent rock. This had been toproped before by someone, but I doubt it has seen a lead as this would be very bold without the bolts I added, but if I am wrong my bad and please let me know!

Start as for Welcome to Ouray, but move left immediately to brown bolt. Continue up face (1st crux) to left-trending crack and flake systems. At 2nd ledge, clip a bolt on the right on the outside of the flake, then make an awkward move to the outside (2nd crux), then follow 2 more bolts up the outside corner being careful of hollow flakes on the right to 2 bolt lowering anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts, #0.75, #1, #2 Camalot, and 1 or 2 green Alien size cams will be plenty. It has a 2 bolt lowering anchor.
content.location: On the Upper Tier, this route shares the start of Welcome to Ouray but moves left immediately following brown bolts.

content.description:
This route is consistent fun on great rock. Start as for

Taliban Tea Party

, but move right after 2nd bolt. The crux is at overlap just beyond halfway, it has a cool pocket finish.
content.location: On the Upper Tier, this is 50' right of Jay's Upper Route. Climb the face just left of the "5.9 crack".

content.description:
On May 21, Ray Hellinger and I were looking for "

5.8 Route

," which we thought would be our warm-up. Because the route line drawn for "Upper Tier Crack" is wrong (#8, p.95 in the 2016 guidebook), and because the guidebook states that "

5.8 Crack

" is the next route to the right of "UTC," we decided on this crack system.

Ray led up sharp, fragile flakes and jugs then followed discontinuous, dirty cracks. Eventually he topped out, using a tree that was a ways back for an anchor. I followed, then walked north along the rim to find a two-bolt anchor, which we eventually ascertained is at the top of the original "

5.8 Crack

." The route that we just did turned out to be undocumented. Afterward, we did the original "5.8 Crack" (which DOES have the huge death block mentioned in the guidebook), "UTC," "

Fact Check

," "

Taliban Tea Party

," and "Rise Above," and have become authorities on the geography of this sector.
Steep jugs off ground lead to pod and bodylength crux crimper moves, then it is moderate to top. An optional short 2nd pitch crack tops out the cliff.
content.protection: 9 bolts to lowering anchor at 70'. A few tight hands cams should suffice for optional 2nd pitch, 2 bolt anchor on top of cliff.
content.location: On the Upper Tier, this is the next route left of Welcome to Ouray. It has brown bolt hangers.

content.description:
This is a cool trad climb for the grade with a lot of variation. Start near big pine tree below a short, right-facing, bombay corner.

It is in your face off the ground with a #0.5 Camalot to protect in bottom of corner. Bust a move and gain cracks up to huge death block at halfway height. Move left under and around block easily avoiding it, one day it will get trundled when no one is below. Gain the large, upper, left-facing corner using micro-cams to protect. There is a stuck cam in top of crack that needs to go....
content.protection: Gear to 3", extra micro and finger cams, stoppers. 2 bolt lowering anchor at top.
content.location:
On the Upper Tier, this is the next route right of 5.9 crack and 35 feet left of

Bel-Loch Diner

.
